conclusion: To solve the problem, I will determine the force of friction acting on the object and calculate the work done by this frictional force as the object moves from point M to point N. I will use the given speed, mass, and friction coefficient to derive the work done.

The image depicts a conveyor belt with two drive wheels labeled M and N. The belt is moving at a speed of \( v = 6 \, 	ext{m/s} \). An object of mass \( m = 3 \, 	ext{kg} \) is placed on the belt directly above wheel M. The distance between the wheels is \( L_1 = 10 \, 	ext{m} \). The coefficient of kinetic friction between the object and the belt is \( \mu = 0.3 \).

premise: The formula for kinetic friction is \( F_f = \mu 	imes N \), where \( N \) is the normal force. Since the object is on a horizontal surface, the normal force is equal to the object's weight: \( N = m 	imes g = 3 \, 	ext{kg} 	imes 10 \, 	ext{m/s}^2 = 30 \, 	ext{N} \).
conclusion: The force of friction acting on the object is \( F_f = 0.3 	imes 30 \, 	ext{N} = 9 \, 	ext{N} \).

premise: The work done by a force over a displacement is given by \( W = F 	imes d \), where \( F \) is the force, and \( d \) is the distance over which the force acts. Here, \( F = 9 \, 	ext{N} \) and \( d = 10 \, 	ext{m} \).
conclusion: The work done by the frictional force as the object moves from point M to point N is \( W = 9 \, 	ext{N} 	imes 10 \, 	ext{m} = 90 \, 	ext{J} \).

premise: The work done by the frictional force of the conveyor belt on the object is $90 \, 	ext{J}$.
conclusion: The work done by the frictional force of the conveyor belt on the object is $90 \, 	ext{J}$.
